raw_text:
Mobile networks seek turbo boost
 
 Third-generation mobile (3G) networks need to get faster if they are to deliver fast internet surfing on the move and exciting new services.
 
 That was one of the messages from the mobile industry at the 3GSM World Congress in Cannes last week. Fast 3G networks are here but the focus has shifted to their evolution into a higher bandwidth service, says the Global Mobile Suppliers Association. At 3GSM, Siemens showed off a system that transmits faster mobile data. The German company said data could be transmitted at one gigabit a second - up to 20 times faster than current 3G networks. The system is not available commercially yet, but Motorola, the US mobile handset and infrastructure maker, held a clinic for mobile operators on HSDPA (High Speed Downlink Packet Access), a high-speed, high bandwidth technology available now. Early HSDPA systems typically offer around two megabits per second (Mbps) compared with less than 384 kilobits per second (Kbps) on standard 3G networks.
 
 "High-Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) - sometimes called Super 3G - will be vital for profitable services like mobile internet browsing and mobile video clips," according to a report published by UK-based research consultancy Analysys. A number of companies are developing the technology. Nokia and Canada-based wireless communication products company Sierra Wireless recently agreed to work together on High Speed Downlink Packet Access. The two companies aim to jointly market the HSDPA solution to global network operator customers.
 
 "While HSDPA theoretically enables data rates up to a maximum of 14Mbps, practical throughputs will be lower than this in wide-area networks," said Dr Alastair Brydon, author of the Analysys report: Pushing Beyond the Limits of 3G with HSDPA and Other Enhancements. "The typical average user rate in a real implementation is likely to be in the region of one megabit per second which, even at this lower rate, will more than double the capacity... when compared to basic WCDMA [3G]," he added. Motorola has conducted five trials of its technology and says speeds of 2.9Mbps have been recorded at the edge of an outdoor 3G cell using a single HSDPA device. But some mobile operators are opting for a technology called Evolution, Data Optimised (EV-DO).
 
 US operator Sprint ordered a broadband data upgrade to its 3G network at the end of last year. We are "expanding our network and deploying EV-DO technology to meet customer demand for faster wireless speeds," said Oliver Valente, Sprint's vice president for technology development, when the contract was announced. As part of $3bn in multi-year contracts announced late last year, Sprint will spend around $1bn on EV-DO technology from Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Motorola that provides average data speeds of 0.3-0.5 megabits a second, and peak download rates of 2.4Mbps. MMO2, the UK-based operator with services in the UK, Ireland and Germany, has opted for technology based on the High Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) standard. Using technology from Lucent, it will offer data speeds of 3.6Mbps from next summer on its Isle of Man 3G network, and will eventually support speeds of up to 14.4Mbps. US operator Cingular Wireless is also adopting HSDPA, using technology from Lucent alongside equipment from Siemens and Ericsson.
 
 Siemens' plans for a one gigabit network may be more than a user needs today, but Christoph Caselitz, president of the mobile networks division at the firm says that: "By the time the next generation of mobile communication debuts in 2015, the need for transmission capacities for voice, data, image and multimedia is conservatively anticipated to rise by a factor of 10." Siemens - in collaboration with the Fraunhofer German-Sino Lab for Mobile Communications and the Institute for Applied Radio System Technology - has souped up mobile communications by using three transmitting and four receiving antennae, instead of the usual one. This enables a data transmission, such as sending a big file or video, to be broken up into different flows of data that can be sent simultaneously over one radio frequency band. The speeds offered by3G mobile seemed fast at the time mobile operators were paying huge sums for 3G licences. But today, instead of connecting to the internet by slow, dial-up phone connection, many people are used to broadband networks that offer speeds of 0.5 megabits a second - must faster than 3G. This means users are likely to find 3G disappointing unless the networks are souped up. If they aren't, those lucrative "power users", such as computer geeks and busy business people will avoid them for all but the most urgent tasks, reducing the potential revenues available to mobile operators. But one gigabit a second systems will not be available immediately. Siemens says that though the system works in the laboratory, it still has to assess the mobility of multiple-antennae devices and conduct field trials. A commercial system could be as far away as 2012, though Siemens did not rule out an earlier date.
llama3.2:1b: Mobile networks are seeking a turbo boost, specifically faster mobile data speeds to deliver fast internet surfing on the move.
The focus has shifted from current 3G bandwidths to higher-speed technologies like High Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) and Evolution Data Optimized (EV-DO).
HSDPA can transmit up to 2.9Mbps, while EV-DO offers average speeds of 0.3-0.5Mbps and peak rates of 2.4Mbps.
These technologies are being developed by companies like Siemens, Motorola, and Lucent Technologies.
While HSDPA is theoretically capable of reaching a maximum speed of 14Mbps, practical data rates will likely be lower due to the limitations of wide-area networks.
However, some mobile operators plan to adopt these faster technologies in the near future.
llama3.2:3b: 3G mobile networks need a speed boost for fast internet surfing and new services.
A German company Siemens showed a system that transmits data at one gigabit per second - up to 20 times faster than current 3G networks.
Motorola is promoting High Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) technology, which can offer speeds of two megabits per second.
Several companies are working on HSDPA, including Nokia and Sierra Wireless.
US operator Sprint ordered EV-DO technology for faster wireless speeds.
Mobile operators are adopting HSDPA to meet customer demand.
gemma2:2b: Mobile networks are seeking faster speeds to support new services like mobile internet browsing and video clips.
Existing 3G technology is being enhanced with technologies like HSDPA for increased download rates.
HSDPA offers up to 14Mbps but practical throughput is likely to be lower.
Other technologies such as EV-DO, used by Sprint, are also evolving to provide faster speeds.
Operators like MMO2 and Cingular Wireless are embracing HSDPA technology.
Future network development aims for significantly higher capacity by 2015.
Although a one-gigabit system may seem excessive for current needs, its potential benefits are high.
However, commercialization is still under development.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Mobile networks aim for faster data speeds.
To achieve this, they are transitioning from 3G to HSDPA and EV-DO technologies.
These enhancements allow for higher download speeds on the move, making it possible to use mobile internet browsing and video streaming services.
While the current 3G networks have a transmission rate of around 20 Mbps, these new technologies promise up to 14 Mbps data rates.
However, Siemens plans to deliver faster data rates using HSDPA technology by using three transmitting antennas instead of the usual one.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Mobile operators seek faster 3G networks to support internet surfing and new services, with 3G speeds expected to increase from the current 384 Kbps to up to 14 Mbps in HSDPA technology.
High-speed cellular data is essential for mobile video browsing and downloads, and Siemens plans a future one gigabit network by 2015 but expects field trials before widespread commercial use.
qwen2.5:3b: Mobile networks need to improve for fast internet surfing and new services.
The focus is shifting from current 3G standards to faster, higher bandwidth systems like HSDPA.
Companies such as Motorola and Nokia are developing HSDPA technology that offers speeds up to 14Mbps in theory, though practical throughput might be lower at around 1Mbps.
Some operators prefer EV-DO for its higher data rates of up to 2.4Mbps.

The industry aims for a significant increase in mobile network capacities by 2015, with Siemens developing new techniques like using multiple transmitting and receiving antennas for faster data transmission.
Despite these advancements, one gigabit-per-second networks are not yet commercially available due to ongoing technological challenges.

The key ideas summarized from the text are:

1.
Mobile networks seek turbo boost: The focus was on fast 3G networks.
Fast 3G networks need to deliver fast internet surfing on the move and exciting new services.
A commercial system could be as far away as 2012, though Siemens did not rule out an earlier date.
smollm:1.7b: The article is about mobile networks seeking turbo boost for faster internet surfing on the move and exciting new services.
It mentions that 3G networks need to get faster if they are to deliver fast internet browsing on the move and exciting new services.
The article also highlights the work of companies like Lucent Technologies, Siemens and Ericsson in developing technology that can support higher data transmission rates.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
Fast 3G networks need improvement  
The global mobile industry is seeking faster internet speeds to support new services.
Mobile operators are advocating for higher bandwidth options.
Siemens introduced HSDPA, a high-speed technology enabling data transmission up to 14Mbps in theory but with lower throughput in practice.
Sierra Wireless and others are collaborating on EV-DO, an enhanced version of HSDPA.
Cingular Wireless is now adopting HSDPA for faster connectivity.
By the end of 2015, voice, data, image, and multimedia traffic demand will increase tenfold compared to today.
Siemens is working on a commercial system by 2012.
tinyllama:1.1b: The mobile industry at the 3GSM World Congress in Cannes has shifted to HSDPA (High Speed Downlink Packet Access), a higher bandwidth service available now.
This technology offers faster data transmission rates, enabling profitable services like mobile internet browsing and video clip downloads.
High-Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) is expected to have average data speeds up to 14Mbps in wide-area networks.

The system's evolution into a higher bandwidth service from current 3G networks has been a priority, with the objective of "more than doubling the capacity" compared to basic WCDMA (3G), according to Dr Alastair Brydon from UK-based research consultancy Analysys.
Several mobile operators are adopting HSDPA, with Motorola opting for EV-DO technology and cellular network operator Sprint deploying it on its 3G network.
The goal of expanding networks and deploying new services is to increase revenue streams while meeting customer demand for faster data transmission rates.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Mobile networks are working on faster mobile internet speeds with higher bandwidths using technology called HSDPA or High Speed Downlink Packet Access.
Siemens showcased its one gigabit per second system at the 3GSM World Congress in Cannes, while Motorola is planning for peak download rates of up to 2.4Mbps on its Isle of Man 3G network.

Global Mobile Suppliers Association's summary provides key information about these developments:

1.

Third-generation mobile networks seek turbo boost
   - Samsung's Galaxy S II, for example, will have a higher-than-average speed on the move due to HSDPA technology.

Third-generation mobile networks need to get faster
   - The industry is moving from 3G to HSDPA or even beyond with the aim of delivering fast internet on the go.

Mobile networks are getting higher bandwidth solutions
   - Siemens showcased its 1 Gbps solution that transfers data at one gigabit per second, up from existing 3G networks.

High-Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) is evolving into 4G and beyond
   - HSDPA is a high-speed, high bandwidth technology available now, but plans for 4G or even faster bands are being considered.

Mobile operators need to optimize their networks for profitable services
   - A high-speed network provides better opportunities for mobile internet browsing and video clips, which will likely require more advanced networks.
The Global Mobile Suppliers Association (GSMA) is the primary catalyst for these advancements and developments in mobile technology.

Third-generation mobile (3G) networks need to get faster if they are to deliver fast internet surfing on the move and exciting new services.
That was one of the messages from the mobile industry at the 3GSM World Congress in Cannes last week.
Fast 3G networks are here but the focus has shifted to their evolution into a higher bandwidth service, says the Global Mobile Suppliers Association.
At 3GSM, Siemens showed off a system that transmits faster mobile data.

Early HSDPA systems typically offer around two megabits per second (Mbps) compared with less than 384 kilobits per second (Kbps) on standard 3G networks.

"High-Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) - sometimes called Super 3G - will be vital for profitable services like mobile internet browsing and mobile video clips," according to a report published by UK-based research consultancy Analysys.
A number of companies are developing the technology.
Nokia and Canada-based wireless communication products company Sierra Wireless recently agreed to work together on High Speed Downlink Packet Access.
The two companies aim to jointly market the HSDPA solution to global network operator customers.

"While HSDPA theoretically enables data rates up to a maximum of 14Mbps, practical throughputs will be lower than this in wide-area networks," said Dr Alastair Brydon, author of the Analysys report: Pushing Beyond the Limits of 3G with HSDPA and Other Enhancements.

"The typical average user rate in a real implementation is likely to be in the region of one megabit per second which, even at this lower rate, will more than double the capacity... when compared to basic WCDMA [3G]," he added.
Motorola has conducted five trials of its technology and says speeds of 2.9Mbps have been recorded at the edge of an outdoor 3G cell using a single HSDPA device.
But some mobile operators are opting for a technology called Evolution, Data Optimised (EV-DO).
US operator Sprint ordered a broadband data upgrade to its 3G network at the end of last year.

We are "expanding our network and deploying EV-DO technology to meet customer demand for faster wireless speeds," said Oliver Valente, Sprint's vice president for technology development, when the contract was announced.

As part of $3bn in multi-year contracts announced late last year, Sprint will spend around $1bn on EV-DO technology from Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Motorola that provides average data speeds of 0.3-0.5 megabits a second, and peak download rates of 2.4Mbps.
MMO2, the UK-based operator with services in the UK, Ireland and Germany, has opted for technology based on the High Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) standard.
Using technology from Lucent, it will offer data speeds of 3.6Mbps from next summer on its Isle of Man 3G network, and will eventually support speeds of up to 14.4Mbps.
US operator Cingular Wireless is also adopting HSDPA, using technology from Lucent and Motorola that enables data transmission over a single radio frequency band.

The speeds offered by HSDPA mobile networks have the potential to revolutionize the way people use their mobile devices, making it possible to access high-speed internet connections from anywhere, anytime.
hermes3:3b: Mobile networks shifting from 3G to faster technologies like HSDPA for higher bandwidth and data speeds.
HSDPA offers around 2 Mbps compared to less than 384 Kbps on standard 3G networks.
Mobile operators like Motorola, Nokia, Sierra Wireless are developing and investing in these technologies.
Ev-DO technology is also gaining popularity as some operators prefer it over HSDPA.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The mobile industry aims for third-generation (3G) networks to evolve into faster services at the 3GSM World Congress in Cannes.
Fast 3G networks are already available but focus is shifted towards higher bandwidth services like High Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA).
Companies like Nokia and Sierra Wireless collaborate on HSDPA technology, with US operator Cingular adopting Lucent's system along with equipment from Siemens and Ericsson.
While practical throughputs in wide-area networks may not reach the maximum of 14Mbps theoretically possible, speeds can average one Mbps or more, doubling capacity compared to basic WCDMA 3G.
Some operators choose Evolution Data Optimised (EV-DO) technology instead.
stablelm2:1.6b: Mobile networks must evolve faster 3G networks into higher bandwidth services for better internet surfing on the go and exciting new services.
Fast 3G networks exist but shift to their evolution is key, according to Global Mobile Suppliers Association.
HSDPA (High Speed Downlink Packet Access) technology will be vital in enabling mobile internet browsing and video clips with lower throughputs.
Companies like Nokia and Sierra Wireless are developing HSDPA, while Motorola provides insight into the potential of EV-DO technology (Evolution, Data Optimised).
A Siemens plan for a one gigabit network could rise by factors of 1000 or more by the time next generation mobile communication launches in 2005.
Current 3G networks' speeds may be inadequate compared to future needs; thus, upgrading and enhancing these networks is essential for successful operations and services.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The mobile industry emphasizes the need for faster third-generation (3G) networks to support high-speed internet usage and new services on the go.
Current 3G networks have been enhanced with technologies like HSDPA and EV-DO, offering data rates of up to 14 Mbps and 2.4 Mbps, respectively.
Mobile operators are investing in these upgrades to meet growing user demands for faster wireless speeds.

Siemens showcased a one gigabit per second (Gbps) data transmission system during the 3GSM World Congress, which utilizes multiple antennae and breaks data into simultaneous flows over a single frequency band.
This technology is still in development, with a potential commercial release around 2012.
Other companies, including Nokia and Sierra Wireless, have partnered to jointly market HSDPA solutions.
Meanwhile, UK-based MMO2 will implement the High Speed Downlink Packet Access (HSDPA) standard from Lucent, delivering data speeds of up to 3.6 Mbps by next summer on its Isle of Man 3G network.
Cingular Wireless and US operator Sprint are also adopting HSDPA technology.
Sprint has invested $1 billion in EV-DO from Lucent, Nortel Networks, and Motorola to provide average data speeds between 0.3-0.5 Mbps with peak download rates of 2.4 Mbps.
The Global Mobile Suppliers Association anticipates a significant increase in required transmission capacities for voice, data, images, and multimedia by 2015, projecting a tenfold rise.
This underscores the importance of continually enhancing mobile networks to support burgeoning user demands and maintain revenue potential for operators.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Third-generation (3G) mobile networks need to become faster to support high-speed internet and new services.
At the 3GSM World Congress, Siemens demonstrated a system capable of transmitting data at one gigabit per second, though it is not yet commercially available.
Meanwhile, Motorola promoted HSDPA (High Speed Downlink Packet Access), which offers significantly higher speeds than standard 3G.
Companies like Nokia and Sierra Wireless are collaborating on HSDPA, which could provide real-world speeds of around one megabit per second.
Some operators, like Sprint, are opting for EV-DO technology, while others, such as MMO2 and Cingular Wireless, are adopting HSDPA.
Siemens is also working on advanced mobile communication technologies that could deliver one gigabit per second by 2012 or later.
As broadband internet becomes more common, users expect faster mobile speeds, making network upgrades essential for mobile operators to retain high-value customers.
